Title: CFPB Kicks Off Rulemaking to Remove Medical Bills from Credit Reports
Rule: Removal of Medical Bills from Credit Reports
Impact: If implemented, the rule would potentially relieve financial strain on individuals and families burdened by medical debt, prevent coercive debt collection tactics, and improve the accuracy of credit reporting.
What_is_this_about: The document outlines proposals by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to initiate a rulemaking process aimed at removing medical bills from Americans' credit reports. The proposals seek to alleviate financial burdens on families caused by medical debt, prevent coercive debt collection practices, and address inaccuracies in credit reporting related to medical billing.
Entities_Impacted: Consumers, consumer reporting companies, creditors, and debt collectors
Summary_Remarks: The CFPB has proposed a rulemaking process to remove medical bills from Americans' credit reports. This aims to alleviate financial strain, prevent coercive debt collection tactics, and address inaccuracies in credit reporting related to medical billing. The proposed rule would prohibit consumer reporting companies from including medical debts on consumer reports used in underwriting decisions and restrict creditors from using medical collections information. It would also prevent debt collectors from using credit reports to pressure consumers into paying medical debts. The proposal does not affect creditors' ability to obtain medical bill information for other purposes. The CFPB has engaged with the public on this issue and is considering feedback before finalizing the rule.

Title: APRA consults on updates to modernised Economic and Financial Statistics reporting standards and guidance
Rule: Updates to Economic and Financial Statistics reporting standards and guidance
Impact: The proposed changes seek to enhance consistency and alignment with the updated capital framework, potentially improving the accuracy and reliability of Economic and Financial Statistics reporting. However, the specific impact on reporting entities and stakeholders will depend on the finalization and implementation of the proposed amendments.
What_is_this_about: The article discusses proposed changes to the Economic and Financial Statistics (EFS) reporting standards and guidance by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA), in collaboration with the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) and the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA). These changes aim to address inconsistencies identified in Reporting Practice Guide RPG 701.0 ABS/RBA Reporting Concepts for the EFS Collection and Reporting Standard ARS 701.0 - ABS/RBA Definitions for the EFS Collection, aligning them with the updated capital framework released in 2021. Additionally, consultations are being conducted on modifications to the EFS Priority Listing for Data Items.
Entities_Impacted: Financial institutions, reporting entities, regulatory bodies
Summary_Remarks: APRA, in collaboration with ABS and RBA, is proposing updates to the Economic and Financial Statistics reporting standards and guidance. The proposed changes aim to address inconsistencies in reporting standards, aligning them with the updated capital framework. Consultations include modifications to the EFS Priority Listing for Data Items. Feedback is solicited until 6 November 2023. Financial institutions and regulatory bodies are among the entities likely to be impacted.
